title: Salisbury campaigner Zelda Perkins who broke Weinstein NDA awarded CBE
body_text:
A WOMAN who broke a non-disclosure agreement (NDA) she signed with Harvey Weinstein has been awarded a CBE for services to social justice.
Zelda Perkins was the first former employee of Mr Weinstein, an ex-film producer and convicted sex offender, to break a gagging order preventing her from talking about his abuse.
Ms Perkins, who lives near Salisbury, a former personal assistant of Weinstein, felt she had no choice but to sign it because of their “enormous disparity of power and wealth”.
She broke the confidentiality agreement in 2017 to speak out against him.
In 2021, Ms Perkins founded the campaign group Can’t Buy My Silence UK, which seeks to end the misuse of NDAs through legislative and regulatory reform.
In July, following an eight-year campaign, government ministers announced plans to stop bosses from using the agreements to silence abused workers.
In an interview with The Guardian, Ms Perkins said: “It’s the beginning of abusers having to change their behaviour – not because somebody’s wagging a finger at them, not because they are told to, but because they have to.
“There’s nowhere for them to hide any more, they just have to effing behave themselves.
“It’s funny because everyone goes: ‘Oh, you’re so brave for breaking your NDA’ – none of that was brave.
“I tell you what’s brave: every single campaigner getting up every morning when you’re on your own and continuing to fight the system with no remuneration, no encouragement, and nobody really there to hold your hand. That’s brave.”
Ms Perkins, who lives near Salisbury, is one of six local people in the New Year Honours list.
Another is Lieutenant Colonel Rory Steevenson, a former soldier who transformed the fortunes of a charity when he took over as a director.
Mr Steevenson, 71, was selected to lead the INSPIRE Foundation, based at Salisbury District Hospital, in September 2012.
He had previously toured the Middle East and Northern Ireland in the infantry.
He has been awarded an MBE for services to spinal injury research.
INSPIRE raises money to improve people's independence and quality of life after they suffer a spinal cord injury, with no government or NHS funding support.
As director, Mr Steevenson was responsible for the day-to-day running of the charity, all fundraising and coordinating INSPIRE'S national research programme.
He grew INSPIRE's research programme from £37,000 to more than £1.6m. He retired in April 2023 but continues to help the charity.

Elsewhere, Idris Elba and ice dancers Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean have been honoured, and England’s victorious women’s football and rugby teams have been recognised.
England’s Lionesses featured heavily on the list after their Euros win in the summer – with captain Leah Williamson made a CBE.
Alex Greenwood, Keira Walsh, Georgia Stanway and Ella Toone, who were all part of the side that beat Spain in the final, have become MBEs.
The team’s Dutch manager Sarina Wiegman has been awarded an honorary damehood.
Actress Meera Syal has become a Dame and broadcaster Gabby Logan, actor Warwick Davis and presenter and author Richard Osman have been made OBEs.
Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said: “This year’s Honours list celebrates the very best of Britain – people who put the common good ahead of themselves to strengthen communities and change lives.
“Their quiet dedication speaks to the decent, compassionate country we are proud to be. On behalf of the whole nation, thank you – and congratulations to everyone recognised today.”
Full list of Salisbury people who have been recognised:
Commanders of the Order of the British Empire (CBE)
Zelda Luna Nico Rabaud Perkins. Founder, Can’t Buy My Silence. For services to social justice.
Officers of the Order of the British Empire (OBE)
Dr Bassam Hallis. Deputy director, (vaccine development, evaluation and preparedness), UK Health Security Agency. For services to vaccine development, pandemic preparedness and overall resilience.
Alison Jane Morton. Chief executive officer, Institute of Health Visiting. For services to health visiting.
Members of the Order of the British Empire (MBE)
Nichola Claire Dugmore. Unit welfare officer, Defence Serious Crime Command. For services to service police personnel.
Lieutenant Colonel (Rtd) Nigel Timothy Rory Steevenson. For services to Spinal Injury Research.
Medallists of the Order of the British Empire (BEM)
Lorna Anne Janse Van Vuuren. For services to the community in Upper Woodford.
